expertSystem.title: A diagnostic procedure and preventive treatment after the first attack of febrile seizures in children between 6 months and 5 years of age.

question.content: Are all of the following criteria met? • fever • generalized convulsions • convulsions lasting less than 15 minutes • normal result of neurological test • no central nervous system disease or factors damaging central nervous system in an interview

• Determine the cause of the fever. • If you find infection, apply appropriate treatment. • Use antipyretics. • Do not perform marking of the electrolytes and glucose’s concentration in the serum or the examination of blood count as a matter of course. • Do not perform MRI, CT or MRI of the head as a matter of course.
Does the child has the signs of meningism?
• Do not identify simple febrile seizures. • Use appropriate evaluation and treatment.

Perform lumbar puncture.
Is the result normal?
Is the child 1 year or less old?

Identify simple febrile seizures.
Is general state of the patient good?
Does the child have bacterial meningitis?

Perform lumbar puncture at every child. No signs of meningism do not exclude meningitis.
Is the result normal?
Has the child received antibiotics before a seizure?
• Discharge patient for the hospital. • Instruct parents how to act when febrile seizures occur. • Do not perform control EEG.
Hospitalization until the improvement of the patient’s state.

Perform lumbar puncture at every child. Therapy with antibiotics can mask symptoms of meningitis.
Is the result normal?
Is the child 12 to 18 months old?

Consider performing lumbar puncture. Signs of meningitis at this age may be faint.
Was lumbar puncture done?

Age above 18 months and no signs of meningism. Identify simple febrile seizures.
Do not perform lumbar puncture as the matter of course (unless clinical symptoms indicate meningitis).
Is general state of the patient good?
